ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Take it if you're into constitutional law. Not much econ. That being said, it's a relatively low work load for an econ senior seminar (50 pages weekly reading, one presentation, and one 10-15 page paper due at the end of the semester).

Yes, I would recommend this class if you are looking for a class with an engaging professor, low workload, and need an economics senior seminar. Professor: Prof. Jaynes was very caring and walked us through the dense material each week in a way that made the classroom discussion enjoyable and the material understandable. Program: Workload was beyond fair (much less than other econ classes I've taken). Assignments included some write ups (short 1 page responses to what we discussed - one was watching an episode of the West Wing). A group presentation (very relaxed assignment that Prof. Jaynes wants you to succeed on). And a paper (around 10 pages) about a topic in economics and discrimination you want to write about. People: Usual economics seminar. Some people are very engaged while others are on Facebook.

Great class- basically con-law with economics thrown in. You lead a discussion, and write a paper at the end, with a few one page assignments throughout. It is a relaxed class that is great as a senior seminar. Professor Jaynes is the man.
Great course. Yale econ needs more seminars like these. Covers important legal history with a complementary econ theory to support it.

Easy 5th class for seniors writing their senior paper; really low workload; class conversation is kind of slow and veers into personal anecdotes a lot; wish Jaynes would talk more or facilitate more since Econ students often don't do seminar that often

Ehhhh. It's not a lot of work, so that's nice. On the flip side, nobody - not even the prof - seems to give a fig about the class. Also, depending on who takes it with you, you might have random dudes talking about how sexism isn't real. So there's that.
